children.subject:
I want to take Data 100 since it seems to be a follow-up of Data 8, a class that I liked for breaking down the math-y/stats content that I was previously unfamiliar with, and also because it would help with declaring a minor in Data Science. Also I think it might a good complement to 170, which I'll be taking alongside with 100 next semester. 

Yes I've heard similar things about 169, but given the extremely high probability of my not landing a decent, let alone a great, internship, I may need to take it. Of course, that would be a decision I would make senior year. 

What about 161 or 168? Should I make room for one/both of them? Are they useful in generic SWE, in anyone's experience? Or EE 120, which I've heard plenty of "good" things about, but I don't know if helps contribute at all to SWE and/or ML/Data Science given that it's a signals based class. Feel free to correct me on that too.

Data 100 is not must-take for ML/Data Science.

CS 169 may not be the best use of your time if you have a SWE internship under your belt, from what I've heard.

I don't think it's a good idea to take Data 100 just to learn pandas or scikit learn - you can learn that yourself. 

And you learn linear/logistic regression in CS 189.

Data 100 isn't the best use of time. I deliberately avoided data 100 and have an awesome data science job upon graduation at a top tech company

What could be a "better" use of time than Data 100, in terms of courses (or anything else pertinent for that matter)? Which course would you recommend instead of Data 100, that is not in the list/s I mentioned above but would help land an awesome DS job at a top tech company (i.e. something you took/did rather than Data 100 that may have helped you land the same?)

@first reply, very true - all these skills are definitely learnable online and you don't absolutely need to take DATA100. My recommendation for DS100 wasn't actually just for pandas or scikit-learn, there are a number of other techniques taught in that course which are directly applicable in DS/ML jobs. DS100 is a great one-stop-shop for learning these skills in case someone doesn't want to spend time learning stuff online or researching online courses/textbooks.

For OP, I'd say take DS100 and CS189 and you should be set.

Sure, that's a fair point.

But I wouldn't go as far as calling it a one-stop shop for learning data science skills, it's a very broad field :)

For one of the follow up questions - sorry I completed missed the question.

I think you're better served by working on some data science projects during the same time you would spent on data 100.

If not for data science projects, take some stat classes like 135, 151A, 153, etc

Been interviewing for ML/DS roles this past semester. From what I've seen, DS interviews comprise a mix of generic SWE questions (CS61B and CS170) and some ML/Stats problems. There's usually one round of Data Structures/Algorithms coding problems for which Leetcode Easy/medium or Cracking the coding interview should suffice (Big focus on Lists, Arrays, Strings here - coding problems a data scientist would encounter)

I'd say definitely take DATA100 since you'd be using pandas and scikit-learn on many take-home challenges and interviews. DS100 also teaches basic classical ML (Linear and Logistic Regression, which can be used for a lot of data science problems). SQL is also very commonly asked and you can learn that in DS100/CS61A/Online or if you want more in-depth knowledge, CS 186. 

You'd also want to take STAT134/140 for probability since it is a crucial part of ML. In addition, you could also consider taking STAT135 or STAT 158 for experimental design and hypothesis testing etc.

The hardest part for me personally was ML, since I haven't taken CS 189 yet. I think 189 is a must-take if you're interviewing for ML roles since interviews involve solid knowledge of ML theory and different kinds of models and approaches.

history.content:
SWE - 170, 162, 186, maybe 169? Are 168 or 161 worth taking too? Any other courses that I may have completely forgot?

ML/Data Sci - 189, 127, Data 100, 126 (may take Stat 140 instead), 182, 194-xx? Any other courses, possibly grad courses, worth taking? 

Just trying to figure out what's worth taking and what's not, especially given that I'm planning on having relatively light workloads on average whilst taking as many "important" courses as I can. FWIW, looking mostly at industry, though may look to pursue a Masters if necessary (for say ML/Data Science based jobs possibly.)
history.subject: Must-take upperdivs for SWE and/or ML/Data Science?
